The music in Eureka Seven is composed by Sato Naoki. I really love the music and the OST is amazing! They're all unique and I recommend listening to them. It was actually the music that made me watch this anime. The music is so beautiful that it may give you goosebumps ore make you cry. And it's not just classical music in this shows, but alot of trance/electronic music by other people.


__________Characters____________(9/10)

The characters in Eureka Seven are all outstanding with their own struggels and fears. They all develop alot throughtout the series, especially Renton does. He changes from being an annoying little boy to a cute, understanding young man. The relationships between especially and Anemone and Dominic is remarkable. This show has alot of romance, and many of the characters fall in love.


______________Enjoyment____________(8/10)

I did really enjoy this show. It's problem is the many episodes before the plot actually starts. Some of the first episodes were like fillers for me. If you don't have the patience, there is a chance you may not see this show. But anyways, don't give up! When the story finally begins, it's great! And even if you don't have an interest in mecha or romance, don't worry! There will be surely something interesting for you in this show.


___________Overall_______________(10/10)

If I look away from the "fillers" in the beginning, this show is the best. Many of the sad things in Eureka Seven is very alike things happening in our own world. I loved it because of it's unique story and relations with our own world. This show has everything; comedy, romance, action,psychological

stuff , drama.... It is definetely one of the most amazing animes ever made^___^


(I'm not an English speaker, and I apologize for any grammar or spelling mistakes. I hope this review is understandable and helpful)

Eureka Seven
Once upon a time, there lived a young boy who knew nothing of his past yet had a dream to become the best lifter of all time. One day that boy would come face-to-face with his hero and learn that his idols were not the fantastic heroes he had thought them to be. But this anime is about more than that. Much more. This anime is about a boy and a girl who grow up in a world of adversity and grow through conflict and strife, given no option but to push forward and become greater than they had ever imagined.
The story follows Reneton,a young boy who is being raised by his grandfather because his father died long, long ago. Reneton's father was the hero of the world some time ago, and Reneton was judged because of it. Yet, Reneton was a normal boy trying to follow his dreams and live HIS life. One day, he got an opportunity to leave him home that would change his life forever, and for good reason. He was following a cute girl that he wanted to know better, plus his favorite idol and lifter, Holland, was involved. What better reason to leave than that?


The story elements in the show build up at a very slow pace. Slow enough that you have a chance to learn about and understand the backgrounds of almost EVERY CHARACTER, and there are a lot of characters involved in this show. My favorite understanding is that of the evil villain. The viewer learns that this villain can do terrible and horrible things to humans and this world and what he strives for is justice in this life. He is able to sacrifice a life knowing that this world will be better off for it. And he takes this to dire constraints. 


By watching this anime, you will follow through many different stories of many different characters being given different sides of the story from adults and children. Ultimately you are forced to follow along with Reneton's views, who is a young teenager, but are held down in chains by the decisions of adults at times. You will want to adventure with Reneton, but see the rationality behind the decisions of the adults and it all makes sense. Sometimes. Other times, the adults think they know what they are talking about, but are too scared to try anything else, and that's where the brave youth comes into play. Other times, even, the adults can be the brave ones in situations that the youths don't understand. You are given a mix of emotions and morals at all times.


If you enjoy watching an anime packed with drama, decisions, and moral dilemmas then this will be a good anime for you. Besides, it's packed with great action and mechas if you are into that kind of thing, or even if you are not.


Last note before the ratings, the story progressed very naturally, however at times I was confused on certain matters of the storyline. The anime does a great job of filling in the gaps very slowly, but few topics require additional analysis from the viewer to piece things together.


Ratings:

Story - 10 - Beautifully pieced together, not giving too much information too quickly and always trying to fill in any gaps as the story progresses. I feel like I grew up with Reneton along the way.

Artwork - 10 - I'll give the artwork at 10. It is well drawn, even more so in the second part of the anime. Nothing mind blowing like today's work because this anime came out in 2005, however it was top-notch for it's time.

Soundtrack - 10 - Oh my! There are some seriously cool vibes in this anime, as they attempted to add a very groovy feel to the anime in many aspects. I have not come across many other anime with such a groovy feel.

Characters - 10 - NO CHARACTERS ARE PERFECT. No characters are perfect in this anime and all characters show fault. We are all human after all and all make mistakes. We are constantly reminded of this through the anime. For starters, Reneton is young and naive. Eureka just doesn't understand so many things. Holland is not the captain you thought he'd be. And there's more.


Overall - 10 - Beautiful, beautiful anime. I'm glad I watched this. It is not fast paced by any means, so keep an open heart and an open mind and you might just fall into this anime as you are watching it.

Recommended - Yes, though you must drop all expectations of how this anime will play through and how it will end. Nothing is fast paced, and you must be prepared for a long build up and ready to enjoy each episode for what it is and nothing less.

Eureka 7 is one of my all-time favorite anime. I believe that if I had seen this anime when I was 14, this would be my undisputed Number 1. However, I still am glad to have seen this at 19, because I could understand the story much better than my 14 yr old self could've, as well as notice the faults therein. Nevertheless, it still captivated me and awakened the 14 yr old soul within me. 
I'll try to keep this spoiler-free, but no guarantees.
Story- (8/10): 
I honestly believe that Eureka 7 had a very good story. The first few episodes may come off asslow (and sometimes confusing) for some people, but I don't think that was the case. The first few episodes in particular showed us character interactions and foreshadowing future events. The specifics of events that occurred were vague but it still all made sense. The first half of the anime did a solid job of showing character interactions, as well as some minor-to-major character developments, with each character varying in degree. The second half of the show was very narrative heavy, but it wasn't without build-up. If you pay attention to the things that they were talking about, you could actually piece together all these information and have it make sense in your head. Granted there were terms and events that they didn't specifically define, it was still relatively easy to connect the dots with other information given. The world building in the anime was great. It got me interested and intrigued. I had to pause and think about stuff from time-to-time and that was great. I don't think my 14 yr old self would've grasped the nature of the world and the events in the anime, and for that I am glad to have watched it at 19. Sure, there are still major plot holes and things that don't make sense (especially in the last two episodes), but that's where the romantic element of the show takes over.


Animation- (8/10): 


I came into the show not expecting a whole lot from the animation quality, but I shouldn't have doubted BONES. It LOOKS AMAZING! I love the Character Designs, the world's style, and the designs of the mechs. 


The one character design I really love is Eureka. Some may say that her character looks bland, boring and seem like a lazy alternate version of another character but I don't see it like that. Her looks were very intriguing from the very start, and you could tell that she was different. The design helped made me feel that way. Her paleness, her emotionless expressions, her hair color- all of them screamed oddity and mystery, and that made me want to know more about her. That also helped me root for Renton. Her hair transformations throughout the series was also a great representation of the changes in her personality and interactions with others. It helped convey the things that the plot wanted you to understand.


I also absolutely love the design for the Gekko crew members. I thought that they were all interesting and cheerful to look at!


Finally, the mechs and the action sequences were all fantastic-looking! The Seven Swells and all the other OP things that Nirvash can do all looked AMAZING.



Sound- (10/10):


This is probably the criteria that most people would give Eureka 7 a perfect score.  Each OP and ED are very catchy and fitting (with exceptions of maybe the 3rd OP and 4th ED: they were catchy but not too fitting). The BGMs were especially great and fantastic. The music's influence in Eureka 7 is also very prevalent and really made for a very pleasant experience. 


Also, about the 4th OP of the series- IT'S SO GOOD!!!


Lastly, if you haven't already, listen to Storywriter- FREAKING AMAZING!



Characters- (9/10): 


The first half of the series really did a good job of showing character interactions and development to the two main protagonist- Eureka and Renton. It also introduced us to TWO OF THE BEST CHARACTERS OF THE ENTIRE SERIES: Charles and Ray. They were supposed to be antagonist but you couldn't help rooting for them until the very end. Holland, however, was especially rough on Renton. In the second half, though, we learn why that is the case and his character gets redeemed. Whether it excuses the things he did is up to your judgement. Talho got an interesting development in the 2nd half as well. As the narrative exposition became more and more prominent, we did lose some of those character moments in the first half, most especially with the Gekkostate. Anemone and Dominic's relationship was also not as explored as I would've liked. Sure the conclusion of it was great but I wish they explored more on it. The antagonists of the show didn't feel as threatening towards the end as well. They had this mysterious aura that just goes nowhere as the show concludes. However, Eureka and Renton carried it. The show's second half focused on them and that was great. As annoying as the children were (and they were very annoying), I liked that they had some kind of closure as well. I loved the ending too, although I wish they showed us more than what we had.



Enjoyment- (10/10): 


If it wasn't obvious already, I absolutely loved the show! I hold a deep affection for it  to that I can see its flaws and still accept it and think that it is a part of the reason why I love it so much. I haven't seen AO yet, but I will despite the negativity around it. I also loved the movie, albeit a different thing entirely. I love Eureka and Renton's relationship, and at the end of the day that is the one thing that everyone who watched this series will remember it for.



Overall- (9.00/10)
