Attention, it seems that this criticism could contain pieces of real troll and fan-boy. Goggles, mask and gloves are mandatory.
Tired that we rebate your ears with the latest television half missed of Gundam? Tired of the deafening hype surrounding Code Geass? Annoyed by the dance of "moe"philes around Macross Failure, uh sorry, Frontier? Tired of the tasteless ersatz of Evangelion? If you dare  speak of Mecha Anime, it will surely bombard you with the name mentioned above . Do not get fooled, I know what's good for you. What you need is Eureka seven.
Sorry for this introduction worthy of a carpet dealer, I wantedto do it.


 Now the critical :


The first thing you notice when you look at Eureka seven, of course, is the visual aspect. The only word that fits in is "wonderful". Everything is extremely neat. Thanks to Kenichi Yoshida for the characters design to Shoji Kawamori for the mecha's (the Nirvash, theEnd, the vessel or the Gekko-Go are all sublime) without forgetting the scenery. Eureka seven boasts one of the best artistic directors of the decade. Bones forces, the animation as the mecha's move in the air with incredible grace. Eureka seven humiliates not only his contemporaries as for example Gundam Seed (Destiny) but in addition this series would almost put everyone on their knees even if it came out as it is today. Here we are in the "heavyweight category", a series that as a Stand Alone Complex still shines for years after. 


But if Eureka seven was a pretty empty shell, I would not bother to tell you. Far from trying to hide the emptiness behind a beautiful façade, the artists of Bones just wanted to create a setting worthy of their jewel. 


The use  format of 50 episodes is brilliant. Instead of spreading unnecessarily, to scrape by repeating the same pattern as a Gundam

The team made the opposite choice: because it has 50 episodes," we'll take the opportunity to change patterns, genres, tones. Thus we will find adventure, crazy comedy, drama, slice of life, romance, without forgetting the fighting mecha". Instead of repeating itself, the series takes the opportunity to be rich and varied, taking the time to portray the characters with the application and the world around them. No episode is unnecessary or free. This slice of life anime is a great tool for development, characters who will gradually discover and enjoy.


Indeed lets talk about the characters .The cast is rich and colourful as in few other anime. Renton the hero, is the boy we were all a little at a time. Living his daily routine in a quiet town, he dreams of adventure and lift, this precisely "surf" practised by his idol Holland and his band of dissidents, the Gekko-State. The adventure will come to him when he attends the crash of the Nirvash a white and red robot and Eureka a pretty member of the Gekko-State where Renton will immediately fall in love. With it, he can join this group he so admires, even if they turn out quite different from what he imagined.


Renton is an interesting character. Followed during the 50 episodes will help to bind him, as we see change in its relations with other characters, and their reactions towards events. We will thus see his mood change and move from its original state "I am part of the Gekko-State because I like Eureka" to the disappointment "I am part of the Gekko-State because I lead a war" and Finally, the acceptance and re-elect "I am part of the Gekko-State because I lead a war to Eureka." Unlike some anime hero who finish as they started, you really see Renton evolve into an adult. A process borrowed from shonen and Gundam but really applied.


Paired with Renton, we have Eureka. A little strange, mysterious and withdraw girl. Her relationship with Renton, far from giving me the buttons as I expected, touched me. We can say that those two are a beautiful couple. Eureka who "adopted" 3 children on a battlefield, give some of the most moving scenes in the series. One gradually discovers humanity and feelings behind the apparent coldness of the lady.


Behind the star couple we found many other characters just as successful. The crew of the Gekko-Go is a collection of colourful individuals with high capital sympathy. I think especially of a another couple, Holland and Talho. Idol of Renton, Holland proves to be a tortured man, a difficult and complex character . Talho, the charm of the series, is a much more worked than a  bimbo at first glance. She is essential as a "support"to Holland. It's different from the couple formed by Renton and Eureka, less fantasy, more realistic, but also with its share of problems. The relationship between these two couples is also very interesting.

One couple remain, the most difficult and tortured,  formed by Dominic and Anemone, which are among the opponents of the Gekko-State. Here it is an unrequited love, that of Dominic for Anemone, super soldier with an unstable psyche, forced to take drugs to escape her crisis, a real psychopath in charge of theEND in conclusion.. We can only admire Dominique for his determination to take care of this girl who can not return his affection, stuck in this pitiful condition to which we sympathize. Like the main couple, their evolution is visible, well-written and memorable.


It is difficult to talk about the story without spreading in spoil, but it is very rich. One of the prowess of Eureka seven was finally to resolve the question that arose since 1996 " how to make Gundam / Macross while integrating the legacy of Evangelion?" Thus the series will mix these influences while affirming its difference. Eureka seven is one of those series that are part of a tradition while adding a stone to the edifice. The story told here is rich, sometimes surprising, varied, rich in emotion, action and surprises. It's both intelligent and honest, never taking the viewer for a fool while launching the pseudo-philosophical crap to give the illusion of depth. It is a story of adventure and love, nothing more, nothing less, but that's a lot, because it is well done. The idealism of a little blue flower that runs through the series will perhaps make some cringe, but if you love it or you ignore that, it's a wonderful world that awaits you. Because it's one of the best anime of the 2000s. Do not wait. Get it by your hands, like Holland would say.

A futuristic mecha teenage love drama story with likeable characters and an excellent soundtrack without a manga to slow it down, here we go.
I remember watching this show every week, waiting for the big final at 50 episodes and it was one of my most enjoyable moments watching anime. A strange love between a human and a coralian with a mech robot that understands them as they have to face the challenges of different enemies that want them captured.
Renton is a somewhat dumb and brave boy that have a talent for flying the combat mech Nirvash, growing up with his grandfather in his repair hangar,his life is one day changed as the girl Eureka needs help with her mech. Swept away with love on first sight he chooses to join Eureka's group and soon finds himself in a good family of friends.\n\n
I have not seen Neon Genesis Evangelion but I guess that most people that are familiar with the show will feel right at home. You should try and see if you like Eureka Seven, don't be scared by the 50 episode length. And avoid the successor Eureka Seven AO until you are ready, because it changes the original story too much.

Nostalgia is the first thing that comes to mind when I think about Eureka Seven.  I was about 17 when this Anime first dropped, and I had watched bits and pieces of it for about a year, never quite devoting myself enough to it until now.  It took me about two months on and off to finish this series, but its 50 episodes flew by before I knew what had hit me.  An enjoyable storyline with a great cast of characters offers Eureka Seven to be a great Anime for virtually any fan to enjoy.
I feel like the world of Eureka Sevenwas so vast and complex that it actually had to take the full 50 episodes to pace its story correctly.  It actually took me a good amount of time to fully grasp the entirety of the series.  Viewers follow the main protagonist, Renton Thurston, son of Adroc Thurston… the so-called savior of the human race.  Renton resides at home with his grandfather and leads a relatively normal life in the land of Kanan.  Normal is quite relative however, as there are quite a bit of flying airships and mech-style units known as LFO’s and mysterious surf-like “waves” in the air called “trapars” that these LFOs use to fly.  Trapars are even used for recreational purposes, like surfers of our world would use to shred sweet blue rip currents. 


Renton quickly meets up with members of Gekkostate, a renegade group of vigilantes hell bent on opposing the military all the while producing an underground magazine, Ray=Out, basically showing how cool they are and what they stand for.  He’s initially a nuisance to the group, but quickly demonstrates his usefulness in “Nirvash”, an almost self-aware LFO piloted by the mysterious Eureka.  Throughout his time aboard Gekkostate, Renton discovers the secrets of the scub coral (the sentient beings sharing the planet with humans), Eureka, the military’s real intentions as well as a lot about himself.


I like the intricacies of the storyline in this series; every point of interest was carefully derived and clearly executed.  The introduction of religious ideals in the Vodarac and the struggle between right and wrong really made it feel closer to real life.   I felt like foreshadowing and hint-dropping was prevalent and existed only when necessary.  There were also not too many mini-arcs, and the ones that existed provided a great deal of value and depth to the overall story.  Filler episodes, which have plagued so many of our favorite shows, are slipped in occasionally, but nothing that would cause one to press the skip button.  My favorite was the one between Dominic, the military strategist and Anemone, the crazed pilot of the military’s most prestigious LFO, TheEND.


I can’t say too many bad things about Eureka Seven’s story, but I did notice that I didn’t binge watch it as I do with some Anime series.  I could watch maybe 3-5 episodes a day at most, but my finger didn’t really itch to click on the next episode.  It’s a good anime to watch on the side, considering it took me over a month to finish it.  All in all, I really enjoyed the story and it is one I will remember for a long time to come.


So many good things to say here regarding the cast in Eureka Seven.  Few times with any series can I say that such a large character-base can be so well personalized and explained in fewer than 100 episodes.  Finally we have a younger protagonist that I didn’t absolutely hate.  Renton acts like a real 14 year old boy would, ambitious but scared… in his most courageous moments he is still vulnerable.  Most of all, there are no harem-y aspects to this entire show.  And I love it.  I understand some sort of fan service is expected in Anime, but Eureka Seven did not disappoint or go too far.  Eureka, Renton’s main love interest and pillar of the entire story is such a complex character.  Her transition from a stone-faced robot to a loving, caring and emotional human being :) is pretty incredible.  Her relationship with Renton is pretty spot on for what I’d expect from children his age and is innocent.  She can seem to many to be a stale, overused character type, but I feel she had enough originality to fit the bill.  The children that she takes care of can get annoying at times, and their premise is a bit odd… but even I grew to like them as side characters.


The crew of the Gekkostate were the strongest and most likable characters in the entire show to me.  Holland, the leader of Gekkostate was a fantastic character.  You were always wondering what he was truly thinking on the inside, despite his hard-headed attitude on the outside.  He always had hidden intentions for the job at hand, even if he was the only one that knew about it.  His girlfriend, Talho provided a small bit of fan service with her skimpy outfits but piloted the crew’s ship while keeping Holland himself in line.  The rest of the crew all formed a great team together and were all multi-dimensional.  This supporting cast reminded me a lot of “Gurren Lagann” in the way they all meshed together so well.


Even the antagonistic military characters were interesting.  Colonel Dewey is cunning and mischievous, and seemingly impossible to defeat.  His enlistment of children to combat Gekkostate and the scub coral shows his deviousness to the full extent.  Dominic was most likely my favorite character in the show… a young, successful military brat whose own morality is tested as Colonel Dewey threatens to conduct the most dastardly of tasks.  There are a few episodes which feature him as the lead and really convey his personality and goals well.  His interactions with Anemone, who he is the keeper of, are emotionally complex and entertaining.  The mini-arc characters Ray and Charles Beams were also some of my favorites, due to their unrelenting devotion to duty and to each other. 


The character base is what kept me coming back to this show, and is possibly one of the most well-rounded and best explained I’ve ever seen in Anime.  


The artists in Eureka Seven did a good job at illustrating the beautiful world the story was set in.  Obviously the animation is 10 years outdated, but I didn’t see anything that looked tacky or outdated in nature unlike some shows made in the early 2000’s.  The character designs were all pretty believable, with the exception of the Gekko’s owner (what was up with that nose!?)  I really liked the design of the LFOs, and they brought me back to my small Mobile Suit Gundam obsession from late high school.  I really enjoyed the first two openings as well the third ending.  The last opening was really odd how they incorporated “Amazing Grace” within it, but I guess it was just me.  The show’s music wasn’t too repetitive, and I liked some of the techno/dance music they played over the radio 


In summation, Eureka Seven is a fine Anime, and one I would recommend to most anyone.  I would especially recommend it to those who are fans of mechs and Gundam-Style shows.  Some of the fight scenes are pretty top-notch and I actually re-watched a few of them.  If you can wrap your head around the world and complex story, you will find a heart-warming story of a great cast of characters fighting for what’s right in the world.  It’s a shame it didn’t receive the proper sequel, Eureka Seven AO disappointed many fans of the show.  Thank you for reading this review, and enjoy the show!

Length: 50 episodes
Demographic: Shounen
Genre: Sci-fi, Adventure, Mecha, Romance
Plot Synopsis
"Giant robots that surf in the sky on things called Transparent Light Particles"
     Sure the premise to Eureka Seven is quite sketchy... but don't let yourself be fooled... This is probably the best anime released this decade.
    The storyline takes place 10,000 years in the future, after humanity has made a mass exodus into space. At the start of the series, we see that humanity has settled down onto what is called "The Promised Land".
     The story is of Renton Thurston, a 14 y.o. "punk" who'slooking for a life bigger then the one he has. He dreams of joining the Gekkostate, a group of counterculture outlaws, and pilot an LFO, the large robots described above. He gets his oppurtuinity when the typeZERO LFO, nicknamed the "Nirvash" crash lands at his grandfather's garage. Piloting it is Eureka, a young emotionless girl, with a blood stained past. But to Renton, she is the most beautiful thing he's ever seen. Soon after, Renton gets his chance to join the Gekkostate. However, he soon learns that the life he reads about, isn't actuality. Renton's journeys are solely fueled by his crush on Eureka... however these feelings quickly become something more...\n\n
Personal opinion\n
     After watching the first 5 episodes, I felt i was watching a happier version of Neon Genesis Evangelion. Then by episode 10, it had eerie similarities to Fullmetal Alchemist. These similarities soon end and Eureka Seven takes off.\n
     The first thing I did when I heard about this anime was read it's Wikipedia entry. Unfortunately it wasn't detailed at all. Following that I decided to watch the openings for the show and make out what i could of the plot. The first opening was enough to convince me to watch it. From battle scenes to the grand setting, it's an ideal opening for a series like it. I watched the first episode and was hooked right then. I'd never had watched a show that had gripped me that much from that early on. And it only got better.\n
     A common complaint I got was that it takes too long for the main plot to start (all the way to episode 26), and that the first half of the series moves too slow. While i can see the former... it didn't affect me at all. In my personal opinion, the first half of the series, although slower then the remaining season, was still quite entertaining. Had the series ended there I would've given it decent reviews (3.5 ish). However upon entering the second half... the pacing picks up and the plot becomes much darker. By the final 10 episodes... Eureka Seven becomes legendary.\n\n
     As a few words of warning, romance is a core theme in the series... so if you're not into lovestories... then this isn't the anime for you. Also, there aren't great extended battles, however... whatever battles there are, are quite amazing. They aren't disorienting (like in NGE and Blood+), but they are still quite grand. Eureka Seven is unique in this way; having a central romantic theme in an action based anime. At times it felt more like a shoujo (animes aimed at girls... has more romance, ie Sailor Moon) then a shounen (animes aimed at boys... has more action, ie Bleach, Naruto). An easy of putting this... Shoujo meets Shounen and Eureka Seven is the result.\n
     Somewhere between the romance between Renton and Eureka, the dark and amazing storyline, and brilliant animations... i realized that Eureka Seven is the best and most beautiful anime i've seen thus far.\n\n
Rating: 10/10\n\n
Similar to...\n
- Neon Genesis Evangelion\n
- Fullmetal Alchemist\n
- D.N.Angel

An anime with a well written story and vivid characters. The opening themes are among the best ive ever heard and the soundtrack is also awesome. If your going to watch this anime start form the beginning other wise you'll miss out on a lot.

I was very cautious about starting Eureka Seven because I generally don't like original anime based in the futuristic apocalyptic setting with the inclusion of giant robots and the potential end of the world looming. This includes shows like neon genesis evangelion and guilty crown (there were giant robots in it and voids are even more ridiculous) just to name a few. Both shows that while enjoyable at rare instances, spent the majority of their running time focusing on minor details and never explaining in depth about anything that was going on behind the scenes, hoping that if it sounded vague enough, it could bemysterious and thought provoking, instead of just pretentious and lazy writing. This doesn't mean that there wasn't any thought behind them or that only smart people could see behind the curtain of subtlety and piece everything together, but I digress. In these anime, generally nothing makes sense and stuff just happens (especially in guilty crown). However I was optimistic since it was animated by studio bones, who have yet to let me down with a series...until now.


Eureka Seven surprisingly has a lot of good attributes which by themselves should have made this show at least an enjoyable watch. However it was all butchered by the directing.


Animation: The animation for this series was pretty good and at times gorgeous, however there are some very choppy action scenes and a whole bunch of awkward camera angles which at times take the viewer out of the moment. The character designs are decent as well, especially for eureka and anemone. Something else worth mentioning is that the action scenes didn't hit with much impact because they didn't want to break up the scenes of mechas fighting with character emotions, which made the fights feel bland and boring. 


Sound: The ost in this show is outstanding and there are a lot of great tracks thanks to naoki sato (assassination classroom and sword of the stranger), and this might even be his best score yet...but this again is ruined by the directing since most of the time the music doesn't fit the scenes. For one thing, it never shuts up, even when a scene would be better silent, and there are times where the music completely contradicts the tone of the scene. The sound directing was done by Wakabayashi Kazuhiro (ghost in the shell, wolf's rain, seven deadly sins, sword of the stranger, and soul eater) and while he is brilliant and this is a outstanding ost, I don't think the music for the series was integrated well. I don't know if it was his fault or the directors fault, but the only themes that worked for me was the nirvash theme and the vocal OSTs. 

The OPs and EDs unfortunately don't fit with the show at all and were a chore to watch. I generally never skip OPs and EDs, but I ended up skipping all eight of them most of the time. Definitely the worst bones OPs and EDs that I have seen.

The voice acting in the english dub (which is how I watched it) was good, nothing was cringe-worthingly bad besides for the hippie Woz, which is weird seeing that the voice acting was done by dave wittenberg who also voiced Kakashi from naruto which I liked, but his performance here was terrible. But the rest was okay, Renton, played by Johnny Young Bosch (ichigo, lelouch, etc.), was annoying at times, but I don't blame the voice acting, but the character itself, who complained a lot and was a teenager.


Characters: The characters are like a shallow dirty pond. They have a dark past and are hard to see through, but are shallow and one dimensional as they could possibly be. Renton and Eureka are in love for no reason and the adults act like there is nothing at stake and that it is all a game, when it is clear that it isn't. Holland acts like a child, and the rest of the crew is one dimensional. And the villain is evil for stupid reasons, if you can even call them that. The only characters that aren't bad are talho, who I will call two dimensional seeing as she still doesn't feel like a character that i am supposed to care about, and Charles and Ray. Charles and Ray are the best part of this show hands down, and they should have been main characters or at least present throughout the majority of the series. They are the Isaac and Miria of this show and every moment they were on screen my undivided attention was on them. There were other characters, such as the three kids, dominic, and the rest of the crew, but they were all pretty pointless characters.


Story: This is the biggest weakness of the series. Since this is an original show, it doesn't have a source material with good writing to take from or bad writing to improve upon, thus it stumbles through the narrative acting like an episodic show even though it clearly isn't since it needs good characters to pull that off and it was hinting to a story that the entire show was trying to get at but failed miserably. In the end, it stuffed exposition and awkward explanations for long periods of time at random moments, especially at the end. The villains motivations and plan make no sense and things just happen with no reasoning behind them or explanations afterwords. I understand that this is a love story (although a over dramatic one) and it wants to spend time on that instead of other things, but the length of the series, 50 episodes, was more than enough for satisfactory backstories and explanations of how the world came to be. If this show was 25 episodes and focused more on the story and less on filler episodes and love drama, this could have been an amazing series. However there is a good reason it isn't: The directing. The director Kyouda Tomoki, never had experience before this. You heard me right. This was his first time directing a full length show. So that is the reason why nothing makes sense and events just happen without reason and the music doesn't flow with the scene and the characters are flat and not interesting.


Enjoyment: I enjoyed certain episodes and I finished the show quickly, but I wouldn't watch it again and there were times that I just didn't care about the show, especially about the characters and plot.


Overall: It is a good show with bad directing. There are so many more problems I had with this show but I don't think insulting it more would be necessary because despite the flaws, it had a lot of great elements.

I wanted to give this show a 7 but I gave it an 8 because of Charles and Ray.

8= Good and had a lot of great elements, but I wouldn't rewatch it.

I had been wanting to watch a good action-romance anime for a while now, and while there are lots of them that I could have chosen from, Eureka Seven caught my eye. I decided to watch this show after watching a youtube video by Gigguk about what's been the greatest thing anime has done in his eyes (or something along those lines.) In the video, he shows a clip of The two leads-Renton and Eureka-embracing. I then came on here after finding the title in the comments and found that I already had this Anime in my Plan to Watch section. 50 episodes later, andI'm glad to say that this show was fantastic.


Story: 7-  The story is good for the most part. The beginning was really good at setting up the world and the characters in it well. It has its ups and downs, but it never really slows down to a sudden halt at any point. But the plot starts to get a little confusing near the end, and it kind of lost me(But I'll chalk that up to me watching the episodes late at night). 


Art: 8- The art was really well done. Bones did an excellent job with animating this show. The action scenes are done really well and backgrounds were very good as well. The character designs were good but were iffy sometimes. All the characters have about the same sized eyes, which I enjoyed because they didn't look too goofy. But sometimes when the eyes would be off center at certain angles and oh boy did it stand out. But it only happened ob=nce or twice, so it didn't take away from the experience.


Sound: 9- The sound design and songs were fantastic. I watched the show dubbed, and it was pretty good, making me happy to take a break from keeping my eyes glued to the bottom of the screen to read the subtitles. The music was amazing, with a lot of powerful and emotional scores, as well as softer more lighthearted scores with soft electric beats in them. The first OP and ED are my favorites.


Characters: 8- The characters are really diverse and relatable. Renton and Eureka are good protagonists and develop their personalities and relationship really well throughout the series. Holland and Talho are Good secondary characters, both funny and badass, while also commanding authority when need be. The supporting cast is good and mostly all of them get a little bit of time in the spotlight. My one complaint with them, the characters seem to have major mood swings. one minute they're mad at someone or crying, the next it's all happy and the problem suddenly disappears. That's one of the real problems I had with the anime.


Enjoyment: 9- This series had me hooked. I was glad to have the feeling of wanting to continue watching, to see what would happen next. It finally helped me scratch that itch of action-romance and had characters that I really did care about. Even when I was slightly confused as to what was going on with the plot near the end, I enjoyed every minute of this anime.


Eureka Seven was an anime that was a heck of a ride. Although its over, this anime will have a special place in my heart...and my favorites list here on MAL.

Eureka Seven is another very well done series by BONES. E7 is a lot of things all put together in one 50-episode package from action-mecha to SOL to philosophical piece, but the true heart of this series is the developing romance and characterization between the two leads Renton and Eureka. This is the one thing that remains constant throughout the series entire run, gets developed very well and imo is the strength of the series (although Renton can get on my nerves at times). The rest of the large cast is excellently developed in particular Holland who serves as a dynamic and intriguing foil toRenton. One thing is that even with 50 episodes, we only really get the background for the main characters like Renton, Eureka, Holland and Talho but I guess that is better than the anime being too long.


The action and animation stand the test of time and still look great. I also like how Bones ambitiously incorporates tons of elements and themes from previous sci-fi and mecha franchises (hello EVA). The biggest weakness for the series is that there isn't a very clear overarching plot for the first half of the series and there are quite a few filler episodes dispersed throughout (even though they are enjoyable). Thus, if you don't keep at it, this is definitely not the easiest series to finish with its 50 episode length. The ending is a bit ambiguous also but you can piece together what happens. The manga fleshes out what happens at the end a lot better so read that if you aren't sure.


Still, this series does a lot more things right than wrong and is very enjoyable to watch all the way through. Just avoid Astral Ocean...


8/10

First impression:
Accompanied by the pop-rock tunes from FLOWS, the introduction to "Eureka 7" has begun. Even though the melody and the text are fairly good, the animation is not the time worth it. It looks terribly humdrum.
As the audience you get thrown directly into the plot. Lots of unanswered questions turn up and you get this small idea about where the show is heading. 
Right after a rather weak cliffhanger, a pretty decent ending song comes out from the speakers, but with a similar animation theme like the opening, the potential is gone.
But hey, interesting girl this Eureka – let me watch more.
Few episodes later…
Waita minute, haven’t I seen this before? With that been said "Eureka 7" starts out really slow. It feels like re-watching episode 1 again and again, lots of new questions but no answers. The plot is not getting anywhere, but the character development is interesting to follow, or can I say bothersome (Renton). Somehow I feel the design of the characters fits to their behavior, that’s an upside. But I also feel like the male protagonist is borrowed from a shonen show like Pokemon/Naruto, really simple-minded and dense. (Don’t remind me that "Eureka 7" actually is a shonen (teenager) show).

The music is not getting many points either; it is a personal opinion though.

So what is keeping me from dropping the show? I will say it is the other characters’ development and interactions, the themes and references throughout the story.


Story: 

The story revolves around Renton Thurston, the 14 years old son of Adroc Thurston, a hero who died saving the world. Renton is a fan of a renegade ‘reffing/lifting’ group called Gekko State led by his idol; Holland and he is dreaming about the day he joins them. 

A sudden meeting with the legendary mecha robot, Nirvash and its pilot, a mysterious girl called Eureka, turns out to be Rentons way to get out from the boring life of his and the adventures together with Gekko State is about to begin.

But a beginning towards what and end where? The first many episodes are trivial and somehow can be considered as fillers. It is first around the 30ish episodes, the main plot starts to kick in and the questions getting answered one by one.


Art: 

The character design and animation are great. You get to see various expressions and colorful backgrounds, but when it comes to battles, it is like watching animations on a blue screen. 


Sound: 

The BGM and insert songs were not creating the atmosphere as they were supposed to. Most of the times it felt like background noise instead.

The voice actors did a good job with voicing the characters expressions like anger, sorrow or joy. Yet again the voice of Renton became an obstacle to fully enjoy this anime. 50 episodes with his never ending yelling are really tiresome.


Character: 

Renton Thurston: A very emotional and outgoing boy with strong ideals and compassions, but on the other hand he is naive and jumps very often into conclusion/matters before understanding the whole context. 

Renton falls in love with Eureka at first sight and as the show progress’; it develops into a love relationship with many misunderstandings. 

He is driven by the hope of seeing his sister Diane again and the need of protecting Eureka.


Eureka: A mysterious female pilot of Nirvash, which she treats like a living being. To other people she can seem to be distant and awkward, plus she has trouble with communicating with others and understanding their feelings. 


Enjoyment: 

The most prevalent theme is about racial and religious tolerance and harmony. It also shows how the media can control the crowd and how easy it is to point fingers in the way to find scapegoats.

I mean I can only think of the recent conflict between Denmark and many Middle East countries.

It is funny the environment theme also turn up, when I think about it. I mean in "Eureka 7" ‘Kute-class Coralian’ appears when the ‘Planet’ (Scub Coral) receives heavy damage and how an understanding and communication is needed to avoid any further destruction. It is almost like the global warming and CO2 discussions we have today.

At last a common fairy tale theme is seen in "Eureka 7". Renton Thurston sets out a grand tour by leaving his childhood home in order to search after his lost sister, to find himself and overcome all the obstacles when he protects Eureka.


Overall:

It is a good anime show with very good character developments. But it is tough to cut through the shadow made by the monotonous sound/music and the very slow story progress. Plus when it is a shonen show where action/battles are the highlights, it hurts to see how poorly done the action scenes are.

One big positive side is the girl Eureka. I must say she is one of the candidates to get the last spot in my favorite character list.


Watch it if you… 

… are looking for an anime with very good character developments, but you must also overcome the childish attitude from Renton and the eventually frustration.

Eureka Seven is a masterpiece plagued by flaws. What I have trouble understanding is why I enjoyed it so much despite this. On one hand, you have beautiful cinematography, a colorful cast, and a romance that makes Kirito and Asuna look like 5th graders handing each other cards on Valentine ’s Day. On the other, you have a profusion of plot holes, one of the worst antagonists I’ve seen to date, and a very rushed conclusion. I’m going to separate the good from the bad because I feel this is the best way to categorize everything. Here we go!
Before getting started, here’s a brief synopsis:
Theseries follows fourteen-year-old Renton Thurston, son of Adroc Thurston – a military researcher who was renowned for his efforts to protect the world. He lives in the boring town of Bellforest with his grandfather, Axel. He engages in a sport known as lifting, which is similar to surfing but with a medium known as trapar waves. He often reads ray=out magazines published by a member of the airship Gekko Go, and fantasizes about becoming a member of the infamous Gekkostate, led by Holland Novak, a former soldier of the military. By chance, a strange member happens to crash into his room – piloting the legendary Nirvash typeZERO – who goes by the name of Eureka, whom he immediately falls in love with. As the military closes in to capture Eureka, Renton’s grandfather tells him to deliver his father’s creation, the Amita Drive, to the Nirvash, which ends up releasing a powerful force known as the “Seven Swell Phenomenon”, destroying everything within its radius. Intrigued by Renton, Holland invites him to join Gekkostate, who accepts wholeheartedly only to find out that life aboard the airship isn’t nearly as alluring as it seemed. Little does Renton know, this is the beginning of a journey that will change the fate of the world. Will he be able to work alongside the mysterious pilot, Eureka, and the less-than-glamorous Gekkostate? 


The Good (aesthetics, cast, themes):


The animation is done by Bones studio who produced series such as Soul Eater, Darker than Black, and Fullmetal Alchemist. They did an impeccable job. Aerial combat is very fluid and each battle scene is complimented by astounding background music.  Character designs are fairly modest creating a sense of normalcy, even though the story takes place thousands of years in the future; there are no risks taken in this area with outlandish costumes, which can be very hit or miss – usually the latter. One of the most impressive feats lies in the setting. The producers clearly allocated a lot of time into creating an exceedingly detailed atmosphere with breathtaking results. 


Eureka Seven features a broad collection of characters. They are all very unique and original. Their interactions with each other are enjoyable to watch and once the main protagonist, Renton, joins the fray he incites a lot of change in their behaviors. As a result, there is a hefty degree of character development in both the main and supporting cast; it is amazing to see them evolve over the course of 50 episodes, which is plenty of time to see significant growth.


The supporting cast is the source of most of the comic relief, a much needed sentiment since the plot can become Attack-on-Titan-esque at times. They even go as far as giving Renton an “important” mission just to publicly humiliate him on camera. He tends to be at the short end of the stick a majority of the series, which helps counter the intolerable aspects of his personality, namely his immaturity. Luckily, he has quite a few heroic moments and becomes more likable as the series progresses. 


The plot touches on some very interesting themes such as the morality of war, religious persecution, and coexistence between species, but in the end it’s the relationship between Renton and his significant other, Eureka, that overshadows everything else while the others are barely delved into. These two build upon their relationship starting from the first episode all the way to the end; even when they’re apart they manage to strengthen their relationship through pure introspection.  They don’t fall in love instantly either. In fact, it’s incredibly one-sided, initially due in part to Eureka somewhat lacking primal human emotions – unfortunately, I can’t expound on that without spoiling anything. Their relationship is definitely the driving force behind this anime and I enjoyed every second of it.


The Bad (underlying plot, main antagonist, pacing): 


While Eureka Seven has some spectacular moments that deserve praise and that I absolutely cherished, they could not hide the undoubtedly large plot holes and poor execution of the main plot, which is a shame because there was a lot of potential. The set up within the first few episodes is vague in that it did not explain what the purpose of the vagrant group “Gekkostate” is nor did it introduce the main antagonist, Colonel Dewey Novak, very well (more on that later). It isn’t until over half way through the series that it becomes evident what they’re trying to accomplish, and even then it seems to lack direction until the final arc. At one point, Renton even explicitly states that Gekkostate doesn’t seem to possess a clear motive. It’s obvious they are fighting the military, but why? I found myself asking that question a lot. Often times, I was more focused on the antics of the supporting cast and the Renton-Eureka love story than the main plot because of this. 


Many of the elements presented in the plot go largely unexplained as well (origins of LFOs, trapar waves, despair sickness, etc.) By the end, I had so many questions left unanswered. One in particular that really bugged me was the specifics of something known as the “Ageha Plan”, proposed by Renton’s late father, Adroc. It supposedly describes the truth behind the coexistence between humans and “scab coral”, but is only lightly touched upon. 


Now for the enigma of a main antagonist. If it wasn’t the aimlessness of Gekkostate that mystified me, it was Colonel Dewey Novak. There are two huge issues with him: 1) He barely shows up throughout the series; aside from a scene of him smirking here and there, he isn’t important until the final arc. 2) His motives lack even more direction than Gekkostate’s; I wish I could say more without spoiling anything, but let me just say there is almost no basis for his actions or claims. The supporting antagonists are far more viable and interesting. He proved to be quite an underwhelming antagonist.


The pacing is good until the last few episodes. I wish they would have stretched out the conclusion into two or three more episodes because a lot happens – emphasis on “a lot”. The buildup happened so quickly I barely had time to process everything that had just occurred, which made me feel slightly less than satisfied with the conclusion. There were some loose ends along with the unexplained elements that would have made for a much better ending had they been clarified. 


There was also one of the most random, pointless filler episodes I’ve ever seen. Episode 39 involves them playing soccer. Yes, soccer. In amidst all of the chaos, one of the crew members says something along the lines of, “Hey guys! I know we’re being chased by the military and the world is in danger, but let’s engage in a friendly game of soccer! OHOHOHO!” No reason behind it, or at least one that’s explained. It was definitely a surprise when it came up and I definitely could have lived without it. 


Overall:


To love this anime, you’re going to have to overlook the main plot. It’s just stable enough to keep you engaged, but it will most likely come second to romance. If you’re looking for a complex and well thought out plot, you won’t be impressed with Eureka Seven. However, if you’re interested in an action-packed adventure with a romantic plot, this anime may be for you. 


Although I had a lot of complaints, I couldn’t help but adore this anime. My eyes were glued to the screen the entire time and I would definitely watch it again. 


I hope this review helped! Feedback is appreciated (:

Like I don't even know where to begin, I guess i'll start from my reaction to my initial thoughts ( Reverse Order). So after i finished watching episode 50 i spent hours trying to think about the ending of the anime it was something I had never done before, I got on my social networking websites and recommended this to all of my friends. Now that might now sound like much but this anime was truly something else. I came into this anime knowing that it was popular and i hadn't watched it because it had 50 episodes and i heard bad reviews about AO( Sequel to Eureka Seven) I was blown away completely by this anime. It came out in 2006 but the graphics still were nothing to make a joke of. The character development was amazing and had you sitting on the edge of your seat from episode 1 The only thing that took this anime from a 10/10 to a 9.5/10 was the ending. It leaves a lot of things up to the individual and i don't like to be left guessing. That's all for my first review ever and hope it wasn't too messy.

The trials of adolescence is never easy, and the prospect of love in the horizon may lead to some questionable choices that can stain the future. But can those choices be reversed, or would we just have to deal with the consequences? Eureka Seven is a show that is in the vein of Neon Genesis Evangelion and Tengen Toppa Gurren Lagann due to its association with mechs and psychology. However, it delves much more into the psychology of all of its characters compared to Gurren Lagann, and does not suffer from dissociated references and abstracted plot such as Evangelion. In my opinion, Eureka Seven strikesthe perfect balance between the two, combining the portrayal of adolescence with the themes of love and conflict, all while saving the world.


Plot: 9/10

Eureka Seven's plot is very well-written, leaving almost no plot holes for people to examine or to criticize. The story comes together nicely in the end, and it has classic points of climax and rising action, even in the middle of the show. Although the falling action, which is only detailed in the ending credits of the last episode, is quite abrupt and brief, it does bring about somewhat a sense of conclusion, that the world is safe and everyone is okay. The climaxes, however, are something this show excels at, as each season of roughly 12 episodes has fluctuations in the plot that keeps the viewer in anticipation of the next episode. The rising action, however, is slightly poor, often struggling to catch up with the rapidly advancing climaxes and often playing catch-up even after. Overall, however, the story is very well written.


Art/Sound: 8/10

Nothing too spectacular here, although for a show made in 2005, it does have some fairly impressive visuals and character designs. The art is crisp and clear, although, being from 2005, it obviously doesn't have the modern type of hair physics or billowing clothes that technology now offers. The opening were also enjoyable, with Taiyou no Mannaka he by Bivattchee being my personal favorite. The endings were slightly forgettable, however.


Character: 10/10

If nothing else, Eureka Seven is a character-driven story, and it fully explores each character's motivations and background in detail in as little time as possible, making them feel real and enjoyable, sometimes even painful, to watch. Some types of stock characters are present, but stereotypes quickly get blasted away, thus the character concepts feel like fresh air. Though Eureka and Renton, the protagonists, do develop the most through the show, side characters such as Holland, Talho, and even Moondoggie have a wonderfully new feel to them by the end of the show. If nothing else, Eureka Seven absolutely nails the formula for wonderful character development and writing, resulting in characters that truly mimic real life.


Enjoyment: 9.5/10

I do admit, the first and second season really pissed me off. But I guess that was the goal of the show in the first place, and they did a wonderful job of accomplishing that goal. By the end, I was thoroughly engrossed with the plot and the characters, while, admittedly, at the beginning, I was a bit lost and even thought about dropping the show. Nevertheless, the little hiccup in the beginning, when everything seemed so pathetic for Renton and how he wallowed in his own self-pity, does prevent the score from being a full 10.


Eureka Seven delivers on aspects that previous, and even future, shows of the same genre do not. Wonderfully real characters, coupled with an entrancing story that highlights the both the positive and negative side of human nature, coupled with a good OST and great art direction, leads to a show that unites the best elements of a show into one. 


Overall: 9/10

I first watched Eureka Seven when it premiered on Adult Swim in 2006.  As I am writing this, we are on the verge of 2017.
I still think about it all the time.
Some shows might have a bit better art or a slightly more original story, but nowhere have I found a package nearly as complete as the one that Eureka Seven presents to us.
As with any great show, its greatest strength lies in its characters.  Front and center is the protagonist, Renton Thurston, a bored youth, the son of a scientist who apparently saved the world and abandoned Renton in the process.His prayers for excitement are answered when a representative from his heroes, the rogue military unit Gekkostate, comes crashing in on his house looking for something that his father invented.  That representative's name is Eureka, and she instantly becomes Renton's raison d'etre. The show is mainly about Renton and Eureka's journey together, but alongside them come an absolutely stellar cast of characters, good and evil.  Fans of the show come to love all of them (yes, even the kids).  I've watched and re-watched some great shows. Even with my favorites, I tend to only end up remembering the one or two main characters: the rest are blurred faces in my memory.  However, to this day, 5 or more years since I've watched an episode, I still remember essentially the entire cast of the show, from the Gekkostate members to the one-offs.  It's good, folks.  Renton frequently gets maligned for being "whiny", but it's a stupid criticism.  At the very beginning, he has the whininess of a dreamy, naive teenager who longs for the grass on the other side, but as you'll see, this gets squeezed out of him pretty quickly.


Next stop: the music. The creators of Eureka Seven were huge music geeks. The show is absolutely littered with all kinds of musical references, particularly to 80's house and acid. I caught very few of them when I first watched the show, but as I got older, I'd randomly stumble upon an amazing track, look at the artist name, and realize, "Shit, that was another reference?!".  Over and over. Just last week I had another one of these revelations.  My point is that the creators knew their music, and it shows.  It definitely shows.  E7's soundtrack is only rivaled by FLCL's, in my opinion.  From the more standard fare of the OP's and ED's, to the classical soundtrack by Naoki Sato, to the squelching tracks ripped out of an 80's club and dragged through '00s Japan: everything is stellar. Episode 35, Astral Apache, features one of the coolest uses of music that I've ever seen in a visual medium.


Now for the story.  It's epic. It's romantic, it's exciting, sad, moving. It's also deep. Pretty much everyone after finishing Evangelion will immediately go online to figure out WTF just happened, yet I feel that E7 frequently isn't given the same respect, though it deserves it.  That's not to say that it is at the same level of mindfuck as Eva; in fact, I think one of E7's strengths over its spiritual mother is that because of its longer length, it develops the story in a more clear and understandable manner.  However, it is still definitely complex, and it took me years of working it out with others on a forum before I felt I had a sufficient grasp on the intricacies of the series. I'd recommend doing the same and finding answers to your questions once you finish.  But having said that, ultimately the centerpiece of the show is the relationship between Eureka and Renton, which needs no explanation and is more than satisfactory for many.  I took a point off for story only because, as I said, this show clearly finds a spiritual mother in Evangelion, so it isn't 100% original.  That is not at all to say that E7 is an Eva "clone", though; even the archetypes that E7 borrows (most notably Rei in the form of Eureka) are HEAVILY altered.  It will be clear after the first few episodes, particularly after meeting Maurice, Maeter, and Linck, that Eureka is NOT Rei.  Even with the Eva homage, Eureka Seven's story is one of the most original and well-crafted that I have seen in anime.


Lastly, the art and animation.  I've seen Bebop, I've seen Samurai Champloo, and in terms of sheer cool, Eureka Seven right is up there with them. A lot of this comes from the music, but it comes just as much from the art.  The character designs are unique and creative, commonly echoing the same rave influences that run throughout the show. I don't think I could have previously pictured what a group of rebel ex-military surf bums would look like, but the Gekkostate characters nail it for me. Throughout the show, we're able to see some fantastic landscapes and cities, with more unique cultures and flavors.  The transforming mech designs are also top-notch.  The show might shine most when we see the glorious sport of lifting in action: the literal surfing in the sky on top of Transparent Light Particles, or "trapars", using a board called a "ref board".  Lifting was mindblowingly cool when I was thirteen, and it's still cool today. In this world, not only do people lift, but the mecha do as well.  Combat happens mostly in the sky, at high speed, with heaps of acrobatics.  For the most part, the show is extremely well animated, which makes these sequences gorgeous to behold. All in all, visually, Eureka Seven is a treat.


So should you watch the show? Probably. It's over ten years old now and it still holds up extremely well.  I firmly believe that it deserves classic status and is not nearly as popular as it could or should be.  But I'll be more clear on which audiences I think will and will not enjoy it.


Eureka Seven can be approached in many different ways, but above all, I think it should be looked at as a dramatic romance. People looking for more straight action, or a more comedic romance, might want to avoid E7.  Also, the romance is very sweet, possibly too sweet for older, more hardened otaku.  That's why this one goes out to the shounen.  If you are 13, 14, 15, 16, and you have big dreams and you're a romantic, then this is absolutely, 100% the show for you. I'm guessing it will be as memorable for you as it was for me.

The story of a boy who wanted to grow up surfing like his idol, who then became a man and went across the world for his family.
From the very beginning the story puts you into a sense of episodic learning, much the same way as someone growing up would experience. It does it in such a way that you can tag right along as Renton slowly finds himself in the world around him. That's not to say however, that the growing is limited to just the protagonist. The scale of the message conveyed about learning and changing is truly breath taking, suggesting that no one,at any age quits actually growing as a person. That growth is stemmed from both hardship and hope, and from making the conscious decision to fight for what you believe in, your place, or even for who you love. Most of all, acknowledging that happiness isn't something that can be experienced all the time, but is something that you carry around with you, even in little doses, everyday. To live in a paradise, is to not truly experience what the world has to offer, as life will seemingly pass you by if you did.


The character progression in Eureka Seven is phenomenal, slowly spoon fed as everyone interacts and finds their place in the puzzle of life. The last couple episodes make you look back on even the smaller details to have little moments of realization about what the writers were going for, both at the time, and then farther down the line with the bigger picture.


Sound and art were stunning. Each piece of music that came on gave me goose bumps, as the score fit so hand in hand with the scenes being shown. On top of that, everything was drawn beautifully, from the crescendo of colours we get during battle, even down to simple expressions as the characters interacted with each other.


If you haven't seen Eureka Seven yet, this is an amazing watch. All 50 episodes offer a little something that you can take and think about.

Let's just get straight to the point.
Plot 4/10 
Eureka 7 is a mecha show about a boy called Renton, who has a chance encounter with a girl named Eureka, stuff happens and thus begins their "adventurous love story." The story shifts focus so many time throughout the show that people just stop caring. At first it's about Renton's desire to join the military and follow his father's footsteps and become humanity's saviour. Then it's about this religious cult who were oppressed. Then it's about this imbecile guy trying to take over the world. And finally it's about inter dimensional beings, a library purgatory, saving theearth from this interstellar creature who has taken over earth. There are many elements of the plot that are introduced but are never resolved.

For example, the show was delving deep into the question why are the mechs shaped like humans, and that was a really intriguing plot point but it's forgotten as quickly as it was introduced.  


We know very few things about the world of Eureka 7. There are these mysterious occurrences called "trapar waves" but we never get around to discussing how they are created and why people can surf on them like they can on regular water. The story goes full on Evangelion at some points, and frankly those 2 or 3 episodes were the only ones that had any semblance of good writing in it. The world building is just bad. We don't know what happened to earth until the third last episode. At the end of the show our main cast has to fulfill a mission and they are transported underground which looks just like earth but we don't get any logical explanation as to what caused that. Sure we do get a half assed narration as to why earth became a barren wasteland but why the underground looked just like earth is never touched upon.


The show itself doesn't know what it wants to do. The initial 17 episodes were boring and banal, but at the end of episode 20 or so you get a scintilla of hope that this show just might be good, but it's cruelly snatched away from us.


Characters 3/10


Eureka 7 is praised for its characters and "romance" if for nothing else, but that's just empty praise. The characters act like cardboard cutouts, there is no sense of depth to them with the exception of a few. Holland, the haughty captain of the ship gecko is angry at Renton all the time, because apparently Eureka like Renton more than she likes him. Our main couple Eureka and Renton just need to have some drama between them. Renton, the most irksome character in the show, is also our protagonist, unfortunately. Characters start beef for no apparent reason, get angry at each other for the sake of drama etc. Renton didn't know his father very well so he jumps at every opportunity that could give him more insight into the life of his late father. People tell him about his father, he listens calmly; Eureka says she knows his father, he goes ape sh*t. Just for the sake of some awful dramatic moment. He is 14 and is stupid enough to take a girl on life support out of the hospital to "take her to a better hospital" knowing that she was from a rebellion group and no hospital would take in a terrorist, but he does it anyway and the girl dies. You might think this would've changed him as a character and made him more scrupulous, but he just forgets about it and does more stupid stuff. I was ready to give up on the show when he purposefully broke his arm using a rock so Eureka wouldn't be the only one who is different. 


Speaking of Eureka, she has 3 children; kids whose parents she killed in front of them and to rectify her mistake takes them in as her own. The kids show no sign of rebellion towards the girl who killed their parents, they warm up to her instantly. Sparks do fly (between her and the oldest of the kids she rescued), and such an heavy issue is resolved without them even talking about it. 


Another couple worth mentioning is Holland and Talho. Some stuff happened to them in the past, of which only glimpses are shown, and apparently Holland runs away from his problems. Let's talk about a normal day in Holland's life inside the Geko ship:

1. Wake up 

2. Be a douche to Renton

3. Occasionally hit Renton

4. Get hit by Talho for hitting Renton

5. Go a secluded place

6. Talho arrives and says - "Don't run away"

7. Holland - "I'm not running away"

8. Go to sleep

9. Repeat


The rest of the members of the Geko are plain forgettable. They kill off the only two interesting characters in the show in the most stupid conflict ever. Conflict that could've been resolved with a simple chat. Characters abstain themselves from interaction, are clandestine about their feelings, accentuate their own problems just to create some misunderstanding which in turn gives birth to melodrama. The villain is just horrible. He had multiple occasions to kill the good guys and achieve his superflous goal but chooses to take the "what can they do to me" path. 


At first Eureka's kids didn't like Renton for some reason but they accepted him at the middle of the series, but at the end conflict arises for no reason whatsoever. 


Art and Animation - 8


The animation is pretty good and the art is fantastic. The mech and ship designs are awesome and the fights, though largely unimportant, are very well choreographed and executed.


Sound - 5


It did its job of creating a cacophony of noises and forgettable pieces with the exception of the first opening and an insert song.


Enjoyment - 6


Ehhhh...


Final thoughts


Eureka 7 is part wannabe Evangelion and part wannabe Gundam. The plot is basically non existent until the last 15 or so episodes and the pay off is so disappointing. The characters are annoying and the only redeeming quality about this show are Ray and Charles.

Reviewing longer shows is always hard for me. Over 50 episodes, it's impossible to consistently be a 10/10 experience, it will have low points, but at the same time, it's extremely impressive to get me to keep watching for 18+ hours. To do that, you gotta do something right, or in this case, a lot of somethings. There's not any one thing I can point to to explain why I liked this show, it's the collaborative effort of the characters, plot, setting, presentation, and soundtrack. If I had to pick one thing to focus on though, it'd be the setting.
Eureka Seven takes place in afuturistic world where people are extremely environmentally conscious about polluting the air, but people, as well as large combat mechs, are still able to fly around by surfing through the sky on invisible "trapar" waves. In this world, the government, run entirely by three mysterious sages, has achieved complete control of the planet following a global civil war, and is suppressing various groups while withholding information from the masses as a whole. What's so brilliant about all of that, is that none of it is explained in a boring exposition dump, we learn it all through watching the characters live in the world. Later in the series, some more complicated plot elements get introduced that do need a bit more deliberate of an explanation, but by that point, it's earned it through making you invested in the plot and characters enough that you care about finding the answers.


Speaking of the characters, they're what really bring the show's setting to life. Most of the series is shown from the perspective of the Gekkostate, a group of resistance fighters...that also happen to run a lifting (what they call surfing on trapar waves) magazine. This weird duality is what makes the characters feel real, pretty much every single person is a soldier that has fought and killed people, and they all feel the weight of that in their own way, but at one point near the climax of the story, they stop for an episode and play a random game of soccer, and it feels totally normal! In fact, it ended up being one of my favorite episodes! 


We see this best with the main character. He starts out a stupid, love struck 14 year old, then he turns into a legitimately traumatized and broken 14 year old, then he turns into...Renton. By the end of the series, he's still really stupid (by this point he's 16, but that's only mildly better), and he's still hurt from all the crazy stuff that's happened to him, but he finds it within himself to keep fighting to protect the new family he's built for himself. If I had to pick one thing I didn't like about the show, it'd be that they did too good of a job representing 14 year old boys, I cringed more than once due to him saying the exact wrong thing, but that's a pretty personal complaint because I'm pretty sure I was exactly the same way at that age, I've just been trying my best to forget about it, and looking back, his immaturity was always turned into a payoff down the road.


I'd be remiss if I ignored the animation, sound effects, and music though. Despite being the aforementioned 18+ hours, there was never a time I felt they really skimped on the animation. They kept it simple when they could, but the visual presentation of lifting was just cool to watch, and when they wanted to hit you with a major story beat, they didn't pull their punches with some really nice color design. It's also one of those shows I can totally see myself listening to the soundtrack just for fun in the future, I never once skipped the OP or ED, and the background music was the final piece for putting together the unique feel of the show, in combination with the story and characters.


A lot of people call this show one of their all time favorites. I'm not going to go that far, maybe it would be if I'd seen it when I was younger, but now all I'll say is that it was a fun show that I thought was well worth my time, and really, what more can I ask for?

This show is Studio BONES' true masterpiece. Not counting Brotherhood because that's a manga adaption. Eureka Seven get's it right.
STORY (10)
A true, heartwarming, coming-of-age anime. It only gets better and it moves in a satisfying direction with it's plot. Each episode was loaded with comedy, action, and romance.
ART (10)
Not much that can be complained about. The art is good and has never stopped looking good. The character and mecha designs are memeorable.
SOUND (10)
Fantastic soundtrack with great mood setters and inserts songs. The Openings and Endings are also good and never dissapoint or get old.
CHARACTER (10)
A likeable male lead who is ACTUALLY normal instead of justbeing called normal but having a not-so-common personality. Renton's actions are ones the viewer could see themself doing whether good or bad. He is completely relatable. Eureka isn't emotionless and goes through just as much development as Renton. The rest of the cast is involved in the story and actually worth caring for.\n\n
ENJOYMENT (10)\n
Never got boring, fun to rewatch, this show will make you feel good.\n\n
OVERRALL (10)\n
It's a masterpiece and totally not overrated. One of Adult Swim's best shows and Studio BONES' greatest work.

Eureka SeveN.
Die vermutliche beste Serie die ich jemals gesehen habe.
Es hat gereicht, dass ich damals bei Animax(Premiere) nur reingezappt hatte und schon wurde ich gepackt. Openings & Endings, der Zeichenstil in dem die Charaktere gestaltet sind der gesamte Soundtrack, es hat einfach alles gepasst. Und dann die Story. Das Grundgerüst findet man vermutlich in jedem zweiten Film/Serie.
Jedoch sind es die Feinheiten; der Hintergrund, das Konzept, die Umwelt welche diese Serie so spannend macht.
Prinzipiell ist alles vertreten was man "braucht" (^^); Gags, jede Menge Action, Romantik.
So etwas ist schwer zu erklären wenn man es nicht in die richtigen Begriffe packen kann.
Doch ich sag mal so, ichkenne niemanden der die Serie gesehen (und verstanden)\n
hat, der sagt: "Ich find die Serie Scheisse".\n
Ebenso konnten Freunde die sonst nicht so sehr auf Mecha-zeugs(ich gehöre auch dazu) erkennen, dass auch sie die Serie unglaublich gut finden.\n

Eureka Seven is a science fiction romance mecha drama that tingles the heart and soul of a viewer's emotions. Studio Bones' success with Fullmetal Alchemist demonstrates their ability to tell a compelling story with intense themes and plot devices. The writers make Eureka Seven a classic through the use of Renton and Eureka's unique relationship. While the supporting characters help to distinguish the importance of the story's background and Renton's longing for Eureka, anime fans become more entangled in wanting to see more of the cute relationship that unfolds throughout the series. At first the viewer could become confused when trying to focus on Renton'semotions, while trying to keep track of the overall plot. The episode layout, for episodes 4-20, focuses on the crew's journey in maintaining their lifestyles and the harshness of reality. But the show's progression smoothes out the rough edges in the beginning once a climactic moment occurs between Renton and Eureka in the episode 25 plus range. The physical, emotional, and spiritual transformation of the characters exemplify this series' evolving narrative techniques that makes this show a marvel to behold. I really recommend blu ray, the animation is pure eye candy.




The television series visuals through the animation sequences are top-notch. The intricate details of the Nirvash, the Scub Corals, and Eureka and Renton's growth over the show reinforces the passion put into this stunning anime series.


Music wise, the show emphasizes on cuing in on the dramatic moments with orchestral instruments that yanks at the viewers' hearts. The show's usage of multiple opening and ending themes demonstrates the change and development of the characters and the show's story.


The fifty episode series relays the importance of communication and connectivity between two races that can end conflicts by just listening to one another. The movie of eureka seven which recaps on the show's finer points, the journey to soar into the sky and become both apart of the world and a hero is a dream that everyone wants to have. Seriously i highly recommend this show, its a pure masterpiece in every sense of the word.

Really good anime. Finished it a couple months ago maybe in NOvember. I'll make this review brief without revealing to much.
Story: Really good. Lots of backstorys and mysterys to follow.
Art: EXCELLENT. Very detailed animation with lots of bright colors.
Sound: I enjoyed da music throught the show. Especially the openings but the endings I could do without.
Character: Loved the character develpoment. Though the characters were ALL annoying at the beginning and middle. Once you get to the later middle you'll enjoy the characters more.
Enjoyment: Lots of action, lots of bloody action. Who knew mechs could bleed huh?! Lots of adventure to. Theres also lots of romanceif your into that kind of thing.\n\n
Overall: Highly recommend this anime to anyone thats a mecha fan. If you dont like mecha maybe you'll like the plot and overall themes in this anime. 10/10

I began Eureka Seven with moderately high expectations based on a close friend's recommendation. After watching more than a fifth of the show I have dropped it. I found the plot and characterization lacking. The animation is extremely good and the soundtrack is incredibly well done.
Plot-
-Pacing is poor at best, after 1/5 of the season all we know is that the  Gekkostate  is ex-military (they did bad things), Renton loves Eureka, and the military has brought back a talented officer.
-The show seems to be more concerned with riding trapars and immaterial interpersonal relationships than any plot advancement.
-Includes fairly stereotypical plot devices such as:ex-military rebels, OP rebels, mysterious girl, rebel leader with a troubled past, etc. (I an not saying that a show needs to be entirely original to be "good", but that this show seems to mostly unoriginal, in that it brings few new experiences and therefore is not an easily justified use of time)\n
-pacing, lack of original devices\n\n
Characterization-\n
-Voice acting is pretty good, but the lines are mediocre\n
-Renton is annoying; he is supposed to be ~14 but acts more like the children than anything else (I understand it is has a coming of age theme, but that should be Renton going from teen to adult, not child to teen)\n
-Eureka seems to be the stereotypical mysterious girl that is really good at X (again not saying that type of character is bad in and of itself, only that there is little or no explanation or variation on the theme)\n
-Holland is a pretty cool guy but my sympathy for him waned very quickly, he seems intelligent but acts impetuously with no explanations provided (he is almost as childish as Renton sometimes)\n
-Many of the less important members of the Gekkostate are very interesting, I believe that is the case because they are departures from stereotypes.\n\n
Overall I have failed to enjoy the show enough to continue to watch it. The plot is paced so poorly that after more than 1/5 of the show I still seem to be watching exposition; the story has not been adequately framed in 11 episodes. In fact, the only major plot points are these: Renton's family had the Omata drive, Renton goes off with the Gekko State, Renton loves Eureka, the Gekko State has a troubled (ex-military) past, and Eureka is mysterious. Unfortunately, only around half of the episodes advance the plot at all (and always slowly), the other half are about unimportant money making ventures and having fun (and the "fun" ones aren't particularly funny either). The supporting characters seem more interesting than the main ones. Nothing the characters have done has had any consequences to speak of. A show that seems to sell itself as "deep", "coming of age", etc. shows very little of any of those aspects. I am not saying that plot needs to be advanced at a breakneck pace, however too slow is too slow. Bottom line is that the show failed to hold my interest and at the end of the day, that is the only reason one needs to consider.

50 Episodes is a big investment. 
Story: 
Eureka Seven is a happy-go-lucky airship adventure, packed with angsty adolescent themes, slice of life comedy and sentimental moments (all of which held together by the mushy, yet familiar, “love conquers all” theme). The story is about a naive, 14 year old boy, Renton, and his journey to explore the adult world with an oddball group of mercenaries. The primary focus of this anime is adolescence, family and young romance. It’s important to establish that early on as this is in no way a legitimate action anime. 
I realized pretty early on that I am too old, rationaland cynical to get everything I might have out of this anime but I’ll do my best to highlight the positives of ES while still remaining honest.


Without a doubt, the introduction into the Eureka Seven universe was lacking. I’m not asking ES to give everything away in the beginning but I see no reason to withhold basic information such as what planet are we on? What is the world like? What kind of government controls “The Military”? Many of the shocking revelations that are introduced later on are actually no-brainer plot points that should have been explained to me much earlier on. It’s like your little cousin on Christmas giving you back the car keys she’d hidden for the past month-- ‘Thanks, I appreciate it but my gratitude is offset by the knowledge that these really shouldn’t have gone missing in the first place.’ 

I would have liked to have had a 2-minute voiceover narration or conversation between characters that explained the state of the world. Oh, and one scene with a comprehensive map of the world like in Full Metal Alchemist. 

As for the actual plot of ES I’m going to have to say that it’s largely irrelevant. We have a plot skeleton and some vague attempt at conflict but it’s not coherent enough to properly scrutinize. How can I explain it? It’s not like they tried to pull something risky off and failed, rather, ES just didn’t invest a lot of effort into building it up. You will end the anime with many questions about the plot. 

Tone: I would classify the tone as a lighthearted and sentimental. There isn’t a real sense of urgency or mortality, and characters don’t display realistic reactions to danger. But why should they? Enemy mecha and gunships are little more than plastic toys that shoot confetti. Every once in a while we’ll see a severed arm, a massacre or a submachine gun emptied into someone’s chest but the moral lessons and horror are usually short-lived and quickly forgotten to make room for the slice-of-life comedy on the ship or the next little adventure. If you’re going for a psychological anime or a gorefest, then you’re going to be sorely disappointed. However if you want a touching, light action anime that’s punctuated with some serious moments then ES is a good fit.


Art: It’s hard for me to classify. At times it was extremely detailed and other times it looked very simple. As a general rule it was gorgeous though. I liked the character designs too, especially Eureka. She wasn’t sexualized or ecchified at all. I thought this lent credibility to innocent romance angle of the series. The battle scenes and the trapar surfing concept was visually pleasing. It’s almost like watching kata or choreographed fight scenes, it’s nice to look at but hard to get too excited about. 


Sound: I wasn’t blown away. None of the songs really stuck with me and the last intro, a remix of Amazing Grace was just weird. The main theme wasn’t bad but not particularly memorable. 


Characters: This is the selling point or the breaking point (assuming you made it past the ‘no real action’ disclaimer). A lot of the character interactions revolve around Renton's 14 year old world-view and crush.

Most of the mains undergo several significant changes as the series progresses. The characters are not amazingly complex by themselves but you do grow fond of them over the series and appreciate it when they start to evolve. I feel like the side characters are underdeveloped though. They get plenty of screen time but not a lot of depth. For the most part, they are confined to a specific supportive role i.e. encouragement, advice or wisdom etc. Nonetheless you still appreciate them.

Overall: It’s hard for me to score this one. If you’re willing to forgive the narrative shortcuts and bland action scenes, and focus on “OMG! Will the couples end up together?” then you might like it. If you have already developed a taste for anime with darker, adult themes then this will probably bore you.


Blood/Gore: a bit but it’s brushed over.

Love/Romance: It’s the heart of the anime if you’re into that.

Sex/Nudity: A few suggestive conversations. I was a little surprised. But no…
